Homarus gammarus , known as the European lobster or common lobster , is a species of clawed lobster from the eastern Atlantic Ocean , Mediterranean Sea and parts of the Black Sea . It is closely related to the American lobster , H. americanus . It may grow to a length of 60 cm ( 24 in ) and a mass of 6 kilograms ( 13 lb ) , and bears a conspicuous pair of claws . In life , the lobsters are blue , only becoming " lobster red " on cooking . Mating occurs in the summer , producing eggs which are carried by the females for up to a year before hatching into planktonic larvae . Homarus gammarus is a highly esteemed food , and is widely caught using lobster pots , mostly around the British Isles . 
 Homarus gammarus is a large crustacean , with a body length up to 60 centimetres ( 24 in ) and weighing up to 5 – 6 kilograms ( 11 – 13 lb ) , although the lobsters caught in lobster pots are usually 23 – 38 cm ( 9 – 15 in ) long and weigh 0 @.@ 7 – 2 @.@ 2 kg ( 1 @.@ 5 – 4 @.@ 9 lb ) . This may occur several times a year for young lobsters , but decreases to once every 1 – 2 years for larger animals . 
 The first pair of pereiopods is armed with a large , asymmetrical pair of claws . The larger one is the " crusher " , and has rounded nodules used for crushing prey ; the other is the " cutter " , which has sharp inner edges , and is used for holding or tearing the prey . Usually , the left claw is the crusher , and the right is the cutter . 
 The exoskeleton is generally blue above , with spots that coalesce , and yellow below . The red colour associated with lobsters only appears after cooking . This occurs because , in life , the red pigment astaxanthin is bound to a protein complex , but the complex is broken up by the heat of cooking , releasing the red pigment .

The female carries the eggs for up to 12 months , depending on the temperature , attached to her pleopods . Females carrying eggs are said to be " berried " and can be found throughout the year . 
 The eggs hatch at night , and the larvae swim to the water surface where they drift with the ocean currents , preying on zooplankton . This stage involves three moults and lasts for 15 – 35 days . After the third moult , the juvenile takes on a form closer to the adult , and adopts a benthic lifestyle .  Air Vice Marshal Frank Headlam , CB , CBE ( 15 July 1914 – 23 December 1976 ) was a senior commander in the Royal Australian Air Force ( RAAF ) . Born and educated in Tasmania , he joined the RAAF as an air cadet in January 1934 . He specialised in flying instruction and navigation before the outbreak of World War II . In April 1941 , he became commanding officer of No. 2 Squadron , which operated Lockheed Hudsons . The squadron was deployed to Dutch Timor in December , and saw action against Japanese forces in the South West Pacific . After returning to Australia in February 1942 , Headlam held staff appointments and training commands , finishing the war a group captain .

His tenure as DCAS coincided with the most significant rearmament program the Air Force had undertaken since World War II , and with manpower shortages stemming from this expansion and from Australia 's increasing involvement in the security of South East Asia . This period also marked a significant organizational shift for the Air Force, transitioning from a geographically based command-and-control system to one centered on function. Meridian, located in the state of Mississippi in the United States, holds the distinction of being the sixth largest city in the state. Serving as the county seat of Lauderdale County and as the focal point of the Meridian, Mississippi Micropolitan Statistical Area, it occupies a strategic position along major highways. Situated 93 miles (150 km) east of Jackson, Mississippi; 154 miles (248 km) west of Birmingham, Alabama; 202 miles (325 km) northeast of New Orleans, Louisiana; and 231 miles (372 km) southeast of Memphis, Tennessee, Meridian serves as a pivotal hub in the region.

Founded in 1860 at the juncture of the Mobile and Ohio Railroad and Southern Railway of Mississippi, Meridian's economy thrived on the railways and the trade they facilitated, making it a crucial trading hub. However, its prosperity was short-lived as during the American Civil War, General William Tecumseh Sherman's troops razed much of the city to the ground during the Battle of Meridian in February 1864.

Reborn from the ashes of war, the city blossomed into a "Golden Age" during the late 19th and early 20th centuries, claiming its place as the largest city in Mississippi. A bustling hub of industry, it thrived as a manufacturing powerhouse in the South, where 44 trains arrived and departed daily, connecting the city to the world beyond. The grand Union Station, erected in 1906, stands as a testament to this era, now serving as a multi-modal center linking the city to the Meridian Transit System, Greyhound Buses, and Trailways, welcoming an average of 242,360 passengers each year. Though the once-booming railroad industry waned, the city adapted, finding new prosperity in healthcare, military, and manufacturing sectors which emerged as the primary employers by 2010. The city's population within its limits, as of 2008 census estimates, stood at 38,232, yet it draws strength from a larger community of 232,900 within a 45-mile radius and 526,500 within a 65-mile radius, where 104,600 and 234,200 individuals, respectively, contribute to the city's economic vitality.

The area is served by two military facilities, Naval Air Station Meridian and Key Field, which collectively provide over 4,000 jobs. Naval Air Station Meridian is home to the Regional Counter-Drug Training Academy (RCTA) and the first local Department of Homeland Security office in the state. Key Field, named after brothers Fred and Al Key who set a world endurance flight record in 1935, is currently home to the 186th Air Refueling Wing of the Air National Guard and serves as a support facility for the 185th Aviation Brigade of the Army National Guard. Rush Foundation Hospital is the largest non-military employer in the region, with a workforce of 2,610 individuals.

Meridian boasts a variety of arts organizations and historic buildings, including the Riley Center, Meridian Museum of Art, Meridian Little Theatre, and the Meridian Symphony Orchestra. The city was once home to two Carnegie libraries, one designated for whites and the other for African Americans. The Carnegie Branch Library, which has since been demolished, was part of a series of Carnegie libraries constructed for black communities in the Southern United States during the period of segregation.

Meridian, a city steeped in history and rich in culture, has been chosen as the future home of the Mississippi Arts and Entertainment Center (MAEC). Walking through the streets where the echoes of Jimmie Rodgers, the iconic "Father of Country Music," still linger, one can feel the soulful melodies of the past seeping through the cracks of time. In Highland Park, the museum dedicated to Rodgers showcases his life and career, alongside vintage railroad equipment from a bygone era. The Highland Park Dentzel Carousel, a National Historic Landmark, stands proudly, its ornate carvings telling stories of a forgotten world. As you explore the city, you can't help but be moved by the stories of its natives - from the tragic fate of activist James Chaney to the triumph of Miss America 1986 Susan Akin. The federal courthouse, a solemn reminder of past injustices, served as the stage for the trial that brought justice to Chaney and his fellow activists. Meridian is more than just a city; it is a living, breathing testament to the resilience and spirit of its people.

The land that is now known as Meridian was originally home to the Choctaw Native Americans before being acquired by the United States through the Treaty of Dancing Rabbit Creek in 1830, a controversial agreement during the era of Indian Removal. Once the treaty was officially approved, European-American settlers started to populate the area, marking a significant shift in the demographics and history of the region.

After being granted approximately 2,000 acres of federal land, Richard McLemore, the initial settler of Meridian, took the initiative to offer free land to entice more individuals to settle in the area and aid in its development. In 1853, the majority of McLemore's land was purchased by Lewis A. Ragsdale, a lawyer hailing from Alabama. The remaining 80 acres were obtained by John T. Ball, a merchant from Kemper County. Ragsdale and Ball, recognized as the city's founders, then proceeded to carve out lots for new development on their respective parcels of land. This strategic move played a crucial role in the early growth and establishment of Meridian, setting the stage for its future expansion and prosperity.

The small settlement buzzed with excitement and tension as residents debated the perfect name to encapsulate their growing community. Ball, with his eyes set on progress and industry, championed the name "Meridian", emphasizing its connotation of a meeting point. Countering him were the more rural inhabitants, drawn to the poetic charm of "Mad River" in the Native American language, which flowed near their homes. Amidst the discord, Ragsdale boldly proposed "Ragsdale City", a declaration of his own importance. The atmosphere crackled with anticipation as Ball erected a station house along the Mobile and Ohio Railroad, its sign swinging between "Meridian" and "<unk>" each day, a visual representation of the town's divided soul. However, the steady rhythm of progress could not be halted, as the arrival of railroad workers brought a new voice to the debate. Their influence was undeniable, and the name "Meridian" was ultimately emblazoned on the station sign permanently. On a crisp February day in 1860, the town was officially christened Meridian, a name that would forever bind its past with its future.

Meridian, a quaint village at the onset of the American Civil War in 1861, found itself in a pivotal location due to its strategic positioning at a crucial railroad junction. In response to this advantageous location, the Confederates undertook the construction of numerous military installations to bolster their efforts in the war. The pivotal Battle of Meridian in 1864 saw General William Tecumseh Sherman leading troops into the city, orchestrating the destruction of vital railroads, an arsenal, and vast storehouses. Sherman's forces inflicted considerable damage, with many buildings reduced to ashes. In the aftermath, Sherman was quoted as stating, "Meridian, along with its depots, storehouses, arsenal, hospitals, offices, hotels, and cantonments, has been obliterated." Remarkably, the city's railroad lines were swiftly restored and operational within a mere 26 days following the fierce battle. Despite such resilience, racial tensions persisted during the tumultuous Reconstruction era, culminating in the tragic riot of 1871 following a devastating fire that ravaged numerous businesses.

The town flourished in the wake of the Civil War, entering its "Golden Age" from 1880 to 1910. The arrival of the railroads brought not only a means of transportation but also a surge in industries, leading to a population explosion. With the rising number of residents, the downtown area saw a surge in commercial activity. From 1890 to 1930, Meridian stood as Mississippi's largest city and a prominent hub for manufacturing in the South. Many of the city's iconic structures were erected during this pivotal period, such as the majestic Grand Opera House in 1890, the historic Wechsler School in 1894, two Carnegie libraries in 1913, and the imposing <unk> Building, Meridian's tallest skyscraper, in 1929.

The city experienced continued growth due to the efforts of the commission government, which successfully attracted 90 new industrial plants in 1913 and fostered a thriving automobile industry in the 1920s. Despite facing challenges such as the stock market crash of 1929 and the subsequent Great Depression, the city remained appealing to new businesses. In response to the cultural trend of escapism during the Depression era, the S. H. Kress & Co. building was constructed in downtown Meridian with the intention of providing luxury to the common man. Additionally, the Temple Theater opened as a movie house. The federal courthouse was also built in 1933 as a WPA project.

Following a temporary economic downturn at the conclusion of the Great Depression, the United States found itself engulfed in the throes of World War II, thereby rekindling the significance of the nation's railroad infrastructure. The pivotal role played by railroads in the transportation of vital resources such as gasoline and scrap metal for military vehicle construction saw Meridian reclaim its status as a central hub for rail operations within the region. This resurgence in economic activity persisted until the 1950s, when the advent of the automobile and the establishment of the Interstate Highway System began to overshadow the popularity of passenger rail travel. The subsequent decline of the railroad industry precipitated substantial job losses, prompting an exodus of workers to seek opportunities elsewhere and resulting in a notable decline in the local population.

During the height of the American Civil Rights Movement in the 1960s, the small town of Meridian played a crucial role in the fight for equality. It was here that the Council of Federated Organizations (COFO) office was located, along with various other activist groups. James Chaney, a local resident, worked alongside volunteers Michael Schwerner and Andrew Goodman to establish a community center that offered classes to empower African Americans in the area to exercise their right to vote. However, their efforts were met with hostility from the white community, leading to frequent outbreaks of racial violence. Tragically, in June 1964, Chaney, Schwerner, and Goodman traveled to Neshoba County to investigate a church bombing, only to vanish on their way back to Meridian. After an intensive FBI investigation, their bodies were discovered two months later, buried in a remote dam. The brutal murders of these three activists served as a stark reminder of the dangers faced by those fighting for justice and equality in the Deep South.

Seven Klansmen, accompanied by a deputy sheriff, stood trial in the hallowed halls of the federal courthouse in Meridian, where they were found guilty of heinous acts that stripped the victims of their sacred civil rights. In a trial that sent shockwaves through the nation, three were absolved of guilt, leaving the weight of justice to fall upon the shoulders of those who had orchestrated such a brazen attack on humanity. This landmark ruling marked the first instance in history where a white official had been held accountable for their role in a civil rights tragedy. Years later, the echoes of justice reverberated once more as the state revived the case, seeking to right the wrongs of the past. Edgar Ray Killen, the orchestrator of malice, was met with a resounding verdict of manslaughter and a sentence of six decades behind bars. In a poignant tribute to the fallen, Meridian paid homage to the memory of Chaney, immortalizing his bravery by renaming a stretch of 49th Avenue in his honor and holding an annual commemorative service in his name.

In the heartbeat of the 1960s, as highways paved the way for new horizons, a shift began in the city's soul. Residents, like scattered stars, drifted away from downtown's embrace, seeking solace in the northern reaches of new housing subdivisions. Yet, as the city's heart bled with the exodus, a new melody began to play. Strip commercial interests danced into the downtown streets, threatening to erase the echoes of history. But the city, with a heart as old as time itself, rose from the ashes like a phoenix, determined to preserve the whispers of its past. In the hallowed halls of the 1970s and 80s, historic districts were born, cradling the architectural treasures of yesteryears. The Meridian Historic Districts and Landmarks Commission, a guardian of memories, emerged in 1979, while the Meridian Main Street program, a beacon of hope, lit up the skies in 1985. And so, the city's story, written in the ink of perseverance, continues to unfold, a tapestry of love and legacy woven into the very fabric of its being.

Meridian Main Street spearheaded various revitalization projects in downtown Meridian, which included the construction of a new Amtrak Station in 1997. The design of this station was based on the historic train station that was utilized during Meridian's Golden Age but had since been demolished. Additionally, Meridian Main Street oversaw the renovation of the Rosenbaum Building in 2001 and Weidmann's Restaurant in 2002, while also providing support for integrated urban design initiatives. In collaboration with The Riley Foundation, Meridian Main Street played a key role in the renovation and repurposing of the historic Grand Opera House in 2006, transforming it into the "Mississippi State University Riley Center for Education and the Performing Arts."

Since the Alliance for Downtown Meridian took over the reins of the Meridian Main Street in 2007, a wave of hope and excitement has swept through the city. The dedication and hard work of these organizations, along with the Meridian Downtown Association, have breathed new life into the once forgotten downtown area. It is truly heartwarming to see the passion and determination of these groups as they strive to revitalize and beautify our beloved city. The thought of Mayor Cheri Barry halting the plans for the <unk> Building in 2010 is simply devastating, as it hindered the progress and potential of our downtown. However, with the Alliance leading the charge, we can hope for a brighter future filled with bustling specialty shops, charming restaurants, and lively bars that will bring our downtown back to its former glory. The efforts of the Alliance, Meridian Downtown Association, and Meridian Main Street are not just about business, but about creating a vibrant and thriving community that we can all be proud of.

Nestled amidst the bustling railway junction of Meridian, a tapestry of grand hotels unfurls, each a testament to the city's vibrant past. Hotel Meridian, a jewel of architectural splendor, took form in 1907, while the Union Hotel, a paragon of historic charm, emerged in 1908. The Union Hotel, a relic of yesteryears, was enshrined in the annals of history in 1979, its legacy forever etched on the National Register of Historic Places. As the city expanded, the hotels began to reflect the growing economy, as seen with the construction of the eleven-story Lamar Hotel in 1927. Meridian boasts nine historic districts that have been officially recognized and listed on the National Register of Historic Places. Of particular note is the Meridian Downtown Historic District, which encompasses a merging of two previously established districts, namely the Meridian Urban Center Historic District and the Union Station Historic District. Within these districts, a diverse range of architectural styles dating back to the late 19th and early 20th centuries can be found, including but not limited to Queen Anne, Colonial Revival, Italianate, Art Deco, Late Victorian, and Bungalow. The unique charm and historical significance of these districts make them integral parts of Meridian's cultural heritage and architectural landscape.

Meridian has operated under the mayor-council or "strong mayor" form of government since 1985. A mayor is elected every four years by the population at large. The five members of the city council are elected every four years from each of the city's five wards, which are considered single-member districts. The mayor, as the chief executive officer of the city, is responsible for administering and leading the day-to-day operations of city government. The city council serves as the legislative arm of the government, setting policy and annually adopting the city's operating budget.

City Hall, a stately edifice ensconced at 601 23rd Avenue, stands as a testament to history and governance. Adorned with the prestigious mantle of being listed on the National Register of Historic Places, it exudes an air of grandeur and importance. Within its hallowed halls, Mayor Percy Bland presides over the city, supported by a council of esteemed individuals. Dr. George M. Thomas, Kenneth Dustin Markham, Barbara Henson, Kim Houston, and Randy Hammon, each representing their respective wards, contribute their wisdom and leadership to the city's affairs. The meticulous orchestration of these officials is overseen by the capable council clerk, Pam McInnis, ensuring the smooth functioning of the city's operations, which are carried out by a dedicated workforce of 570 individuals.

Following the devastation of Hurricane Katrina in 2005, our city took a proactive approach to disaster preparedness by establishing its own Department of Homeland Security (DHS) - the only one of its kind in the state. This move was a testament to the resilience and determination of our community in the face of adversity. With a dedicated team overseeing a vast area of nine counties, the DHS has become a beacon of hope and support in times of crisis. Through grants and partnerships with organizations like the Mississippi Emergency Management Agency, the department has been able to provide essential training to law enforcement officers and civilians alike. Personally, I have witnessed the DHS's impact firsthand during Hurricane Ivan in September 2005, when they worked tirelessly to establish shelters for hundreds of evacuees. Their unwavering commitment to our safety and well-being is a source of pride for our city, as we now lead one of the task forces within the Mississippi DHS - a true testament to our strength and unity in the face of adversity.

Situated close by is the East Mississippi Correctional Facility, managed by the GEO Group for the Mississippi Department of Corrections. Heading the Meridian Fire Department is Chief Anthony Clayton, whose team responded to over 1600 calls in 2009, which included 123 structural fires and 609 emergency service calls.

Before the transition to the Republican Party, white voters in the area predominantly supported Democratic Party candidates, as Mississippi had been a one-party state for decades starting from the late nineteenth century.

Meridian is situated in the North Central Hills region of Mississippi, specifically in Lauderdale County. In the early days of Meridian, education was a fledgling endeavor, rooted in the principles of the 1870 Mississippi Constitution. From 1870 to 1885, a select group of trustees, handpicked by the City Council, held sway over the Board of School Directors, wielding the power to guide the operation of the city's schools. Prior to 1884, a smattering of schools dotted the city landscape, but they were mere shadows of what was to come, accommodating a paltry 400 students under private ownership. It wasn't until the crisp September air of 1884 that Meridian saw the birth of its first publicly-owned school. The inaugural public school for the city's black population found its humble beginnings within the rented walls of St. Paul Methodist Church. With the stroke of legislative pen in January 1888, the Mississippi Legislature breathed life into the city charter, granting Meridian the authority to establish its own municipal school district. By March of that same year, the nod of approval for $30,000 in bonds paved the way for the construction of new public schools. Thus, from the ashes of bureaucratic red tape rose the Wechsler School in 1894, a beacon of hope and progress, proudly standing as the first brick-built public school for blacks in the state.

From its humble beginnings in the early district to its current expansive size, the Meridian Public School District has flourished over the years. With six elementary schools, three middle schools, and three high schools, the district offers a comprehensive education to its students. In addition to these public schools, Meridian is also home to several private institutions such as Lamar School, Calvary Christian School, Community Christian School, and St. Patrick's Catholic School. The campus of Meridian High School, the district's flagship high school, sprawls across 37 acres and boasts six buildings and 111 classrooms. With grades 10 through 12 and an enrollment of approximately 1,500 students, Meridian High School is a beacon of education and opportunity for the youth of our community.

Meridian is the proud host of two post-secondary educational institutions. Meridian Community College, established in 1937, can be found at 910 Highway 19 N. It offers free tuition for four semesters to graduates from the Meridian Public and Lauderdale County School Districts, as well as homeschooled children residing within Lauderdale County. Originally known as Meridian Junior College and situated at Meridian High School, the college relocated to its current address in 1965. Following the passage of desegregation laws, Meridian Junior College merged with T.J. Harris Junior College in 1970, which had previously enrolled African-American students. The institution officially changed its name to Meridian Community College in 1987, a move aimed at better reflecting the diverse range of opportunities it provides for the community. Additionally, Mississippi State University maintains a campus in the city, drawing in 763 students from 33 counties in Mississippi and several in Alabama as of the Fall 2008 semester.
